questions.text: Which of the following conditions has a barium enema as shown in the picture below?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Diverticulosis

Diverticulosis

Definition

Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.

Etiology

Diet: A low-fiber diet increases colon pressure.

Age: More common in those over 60.

Genetics: Family history may increase risk.

Pathophysiology

Increased pressure: High colon pressure causes weak spots to bulge.

Weak colonic wall: Weak areas, especially where blood vessels enter the mucosa, are prone to forming diverticula.

Characteristics

False diverticula: Involve only the mucosa and submucosa.

Multiple and acquired: Typically multiple and not congenital.

Location: Most commonly in the sigmoid colon, along the mesenteric aspect.

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic; may include mild abdominal discomfort, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.

Diagnosis

 

Colonoscopy: Direct visualization.

CT Scan: Detailed images of the colon.

Barium enema: Less common, shows a characteristic sawtooth appearance

Management

Diet: Increase fiber intake.

Hydration: Drink plenty of fluids.

Exercise: Promotes healthy bowel function.

Complications

Lower GI Bleed: Common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was managed upon arrival at the emergency room, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45mmHg, and exhibiting hyper-resonance on the left side of the chest, what is the appropriate action based on the findings from the chest x-ray?

questions.correct_answer: B. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

Tension Pneumothorax

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak.
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5th intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
  • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
    • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
    • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
    • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

questions.explanation:
Marjolin’s Ulcer

Definition

Low-grade Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Common Sites of Development
  • Post-burn scar
  • Long-standing venous ulcer
  • Chronic ulcer due to trauma
  • Chronic discharging osteomyelitis sinus
  • Post-radiation ulcer

Pathophysiology

Develops in scar tissue due to chronic irritation

Characteristic Features
  • Painless (no nerves in scar tissues)
  • Slow growing
  • No regional LN metastasis (no lymphatics in scar tissue)

Investigation of Choice

Biopsy

Management
  • Wide local excision followed by a flap cover
  • Radiotherapy should be avoided (as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative end arteritis)

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is?
Identify the procedure shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Whipple’s procedu

Whipple’s procedure

(pancreaticoduodenectomy)

Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct.

Types:

  • Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure
  • Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

Indications

Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localized to the head of the pancreas.

Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management.

Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct, and ampulla of Vater.

Procedure Steps

Tumor Assessment: Explore abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread.

Resection: Remove head of pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection.

Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

 

 

Reconstruction

Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect remaining pancreas to jejunum. Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to jejunum. Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles

Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing.

Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy

Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications
  • Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues.
  • Delayed Gastric Emptying
  • Bleeding, wound infection
  • Reoperation, increased mortality
  • Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple; pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

questions.text: A 30-year old male with gradual progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Image of the swelling on the x-ray film is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description

  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected

Malignancy

What is the current stage of the disease in a patient who presents with hip pain and true shortening of the limb, and is diagnosed with tuberculosis of the hip?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Clinical Findings

X-ray findings

Stage I: Synovitis

(Option A)
  • Irritable hip
  • Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation)
  • Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis)
  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

 

Stage II: Early Arthritis

(Option B)

 
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis

(Option C)

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation

/severe arthritis

(Option D)

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening

 
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

Clinical features:

  • Nerve injury: rare

questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)

Which of the following options is correct with respect to a fed state? 1. Insulin secretion is more 2. Glucagon secretion is less 3. Insulin secretions is less 4. Glucagon secretion is more
questions.explanation:
• Fed or anabolic state occurs immediately after a meal when the energy of nutrients (carbohydrate, protein, or fat) is transferred to high energy compounds for immediate use or for storage. Peripheral tissues (predominantly skeletal muscle) buffer ingested glucose by storing it as glycogen.
  • Fasted or catabolic state occurs later when the level of available nutrients decreases in the blood, and the stored reserves (initially glycogen) are mobilized to perform work or to generate heat. During prolonged fasting, fat oxidation and ketone bodies are used to meet whole body energy requirements.

A patient presents with acute swelling in the big toe, and his serum uric acid levels were increased. The doctor prescribed medicine to manage this acute condition. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Neutrophil chemotaxis prevention

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine  (spindle poison)
  • MOA: Microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors  (Option C)
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver.

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents (Option B)
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: What treatment can be administered to a patient brought to the emergency department with symptoms of diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, salivation, a garlicky odor, a pulse rate of 55/min, and a plasma cholinesterase level of 50 U/mL?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Atropine

Organophosphate poisoning

Common exposures
  • Pesticide: Farmer/field worker, pediatric ingestion, suicide attempt
  • Nerve agent: Multiple patients presenting with similar symptoms

Manifestations

 

Muscarinic (DUMBBELSS) :

  • D-Diarrhea
  • U-Urination
  • M-Miosis
  • B-Bronchospasms, bronchorrhea, bradycardia
  • E-Excitation, Emesis
  • L-Lacrimation
  • S-Salivation, sweating

Nicotinic:

  • Muscle weakness, paralysis, fasciculations.

Management
  • Decontamination
  • Atropine reverses muscarinic symptoms
  • Pralidoxime reverses nicotinic and muscarinic symptoms (reactivates cholinesterase)

questions.text: The co-factor for glutathione peroxidase is:

A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localised erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, and the fluctuation test is positive. Mild axillary lymphadenopathy is on the affected side, and the contralateral breast is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Breast abscess

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms
  • Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, and culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

MOA

  • Enhance Insulin Secretion from the pancreas in response to meals. (no risk of hypoglycemia)
  • Reduce Glucagon Secretion
  • Maintain neutral weight

Uses

Drugs
  • Linagliptin: Safe in renal failure
  • Teneligliptin: Safe in renal failure
  • Vildagliptin: Hepatotoxic
  • Alogliptin
  • Sitagliptin
  • Saxagliptin:
    • Metabolised by CYP3A4, it has more drug interactions.
    • Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.
    • Risk of congestive heart failure.

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
    • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presented with a swelling in her neck. She had an exposure to radiation in the past. Identify the type of disease, image of FNAC is given below:
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Papillary Carcinoma

Feature

Details

Definition

Most common thyroid malignancy (80–85%) with excellent prognosis.

Risk Factors

Childhood radiation exposure, BRAF & RET/PTC mutations, family history.

Spread

Lymphatic spread (cervical lymph nodes commonly affected).

Clinical Features

Painless thyroid nodule, cervical lymphadenopathy, euthyroid state.

Histopathology

Orphan Annie eye nuclei, Psammoma bodies, Nuclear grooves, Papillary structures with fibrovascular cores.

Diagnosis

1. Ultrasound – Microcalcifications, hypoechoic nodule, irregular margins. 2. FNAC – First-line test.

Treatment

1. Total thyroidectomy (>1 cm, multifocal, lymph node involvement). 2. Lobectomy (<1 cm, no metastasis). 3. RAI therapy (for residual disease or metastasis). 4. TSH suppression therapy (Levothyroxine).

Prognosis

Excellent (>95% 10-year survival). Worse with older age, distant metastasis, large tumor size, BRAF mutation.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 14-year-old boy who is experiencing sudden scrotal pain, where physical examination reveals a swollen and red scrotum with the right testes being retracted, absent cremasteric reflex, and negative Prehn's sign?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer C) Right testicu

Direction of Rotation
  • Right Testis: Rotates clockwise
  • Left Testis: Rotates counterclockwise

Predisposing Factors
  • Inversion of the Testis
  • High Investment in Tunica Vaginalis
  • Gap Between Testis and Epididymis
  • Heavy Straining

Features
  • Age Group: Common in children and adolescents
  • Symptoms: Sudden onset of pain in the scrotum, groin, and lower abdomen; vomiting due to pylorospasm
  • Signs: Tenderness, redness, and edema of the scrotal skin
  • Deming's Sign: Affected testis is positioned high due to twisting and cremaster muscle spasm
  • Angell's Sign: Opposite testis lies horizontally due to the presence of mesorchium

Investigations
  • WBC Count: Elevated levels
  • Doppler Study: To assess testicular artery pulsation
  • Ultrasound Abdomen

Treatment
  • Emergency Exploration: Scrotum exploration and untwisting of the testis. The viability of the testis is checked.
  • Fixation: If viable, the testis is fixed to the scrotal sac with 2-3 interrupted nonabsorbable sutures (Prolene).
  • Timing: If surgery occurs within 12-24 hours, viability may be retained. Any delay can lead to gangrene, requiring orchidectomy.
  • Orchidectomy Consideration: If in doubt, the testis can be retained temporarily, with orchidectomy postponed to assess viability.
  • Postoperative Care: A repeat Doppler study confirms viability. The opposite testis should also be fixed to prevent torsion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with a low-grade fever of 1-week duration associated with loss of appetite and weight loss. Barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Ileocaecal TB

Feature

Details

Definition

A form of abdominal tuberculosis affecting the ileocecal region, the most common site of gastrointestinal TB.

Why the Ileocecal Region?

Rich in lymphoid tissue, slow transit time, and increased uptake of tubercle bacilli.

Common Symptoms

Right lower quadrant (RLQ) pain, weight loss, fever, diarrhoea/constipation, and abdominal mass.

Differential Diagnoses

Crohn’s disease, appendicitis, colorectal cancer, lymphoma.

Physical Examination

RLQ tenderness, palpable mass, signs of obstruction (in severe cases).

Imaging Findings

Ultrasound/CT scan: Bowel wall thickening, lymphadenopathy, ascites, strictures.

Endoscopic Findings

Colonoscopy: Ulcers, nodularity, strictures in the ileocecal region.

Histopathology

Caseating granulomas, acid-fast bacilli (AFB) on Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

Definitive Diagnosis

AFB culture, PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Treatment

Anti-TB Therapy (ATT): Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol (2 months), followed by Rifampicin + Isoniazid (4 months).

Indications for Surgery

Bowel obstruction, perforation, abscess, stricture, and unresponsiveness to ATT.

Surgical Options

Limited resection (if necessary), stricturoplasty (for non-resectable strictures).

questions.correct_answer: A. Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component:

Bormann Type

Macroscopic Appearance

Key Features

Type I (Polypoid type)

Polypoid or fungating mass

Well-defined borders, grow into the lumen, minimal invasion into the gastric wall, mand ay have a small ulcerated component.

Type II (Ulcerated tumor with distinct borders)

Ulcerated lesion with raised margins

Clearly defined infiltrative edges, but not deeply penetrating into surrounding tissues. (Option B ruled out)

Type III (Ulceroinfiltrative type)

(Option C ruled out)

Deep ulceration with infiltrative margins

Irregular and poorly defined borders, penetrate deeper into the gastric wall, more aggressive than Type II.

Type IV (Diffuse/Infiltrative type – Linitis Plastica)

(Option D ruled out)

Diffuse thickening of the stomach wall

Infiltrative growth without a discrete mass, causes "a leather bottle stomach" appearance, commonly associated with signet-ring cell carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 60-year-old male who is experiencing lower back pain and has sclerotic lesions in the vertebrae?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology

Prostate cancer spreads hematogenously to bones, commonly affecting the spine, pelvis, ribs, and femur. Metastases are osteoblastic (sclerotic) due to increased osteoblast activity.

Common Symptoms

Lower back pain, pathological fractures, urinary symptoms (hesitancy, frequency), and neurological deficits if spinal cord compression occurs.

Laboratory Findings

PSA – Elevated, ALP – Elevated (bone involvement), Serum Calcium – Normal/mildly elevated (osteoblastic metastases do not cause severe hypercalcemia).

X-ray Findings

Sclerotic (osteoblastic) lesions in vertebrae, pelvis, and long bones.

Bone Scan (Tc-99m)

Shows increased radiotracer uptake in metastatic sites (best for early detection).

MRI Spine

Detects spinal cord compression marrow infiltration.

CT Pelvis/Spine

Defines bone metastases and local spread.

Confirmatory Test

TRUS-guided prostate biopsy (Transrectal Ultrasound Biopsy).

Treatment

Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) (GnRH agonists like Leuprolide), Bisphosphonates for bone health, Radiation for spinal metastases, and Surgical decompression if cord compression occurs.

questions.text: A patient with a history of trauma has a ruptured bulbar urethra. What is the location for the accumulation of urine?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Superficial pouch

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

 

 
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

 

 

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

questions.text: In a newborn male with an undeveloped scrotum, the testis was observed to be located near the peritoneum. Which of the following factors aids in the descent of the testis into the scrotum?

options.label: D
options.text: Manually bring the testis down to the bottom of scrotum.

questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) GnRH Analogu

Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism)

Definition
  • Cryptorchidism is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum from the abdomen.

Locations
  • Inguinal/Palpable undescended testis: 80%
  • Abdominal/Non-Palpable undescended testis: 20%

Causes and Associated Conditions
  • Developmental and Genetic Factors: Conditions like Klinefelter syndrome and testosterone imbalances can impair testicular descent.
  • Prematurity and Maternal Factors: Premature birth and maternal issues like diabetes or medication exposure can lead to undescended testes.
  • Mechanical and Physical Factors: Obstructions in the inguinal canal, scrotum, or related conditions such as inguinal hernia can prevent normal testicular descent.

Complications

(SATHI Mnemonic):

  • S: Sterility - Elevated abdominal temperature can impair sperm production, leading to potential infertility if untreated.
  • A: Atrophy - Prolonged exposure to heat can cause the testis to shrink or become non-functional.
  • T: Trauma, Tumor, Torsion - Increased risk of testicular torsion, which can cause severe pain and potentially result in testicular loss. The most common tumor associated is seminoma, with the highest risk of tumor development in abdominal testes.
  • H: Hernia - Over 90% of cases are associated with a patent processus vaginalis, increasing the risk of inguinal hernia.
  • I: Inflammation - The undescended testis is more prone to inflammatory conditions.

Note: Leydig cells are unaffected, maintaining secondary sexual characteristics, while Sertoli cells are impaired, affecting spermatogenesis.

Diagnosis
  • Palpable undescended testis: Inguinal exploration.
  • Non-Palpable undescended testis: Diagnostic laparoscopy.
  • Imaging: Ultrasound or MRI may be utilised to locate the testis.

Treatment

Surgical Repositioning (Orchidopexy): Usually performed when the child is between 6-12 months old.

Types of Orchidopexy

  • Ombridannes
  • Keetley-Torek
  • Stephen-Fowler
  • Ladd & Gross

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with scrotal enlargement. His LDH levels are notably elevated, while HCG and alpha-fetoprotein levels remain within normal ranges. Upon histopathological examination, the findings are as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Tumor Type

Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumour in men aged 25-45

Origin

Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules

Clinical Features

Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia

Diagnostic Markers

AFP: Normal

hCG: Normal or mildly elevated

LDH: Elevated

Investigation

Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass

Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli

 

FNAC: Contraindicated due to the risk of tumour cell seeding and lymph node metastasis

Treatment

Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy

Adjuvant: Radiation therapy or chemotherapy for positive lymph nodes

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery, for which she was immobilised. Patient started complaining of leg pain on the 5th postoperative day. On examination , Homan’s sign is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Deep Venous thrombosis

Clinical Feature

Significance

Localized tenderness

Specific for DVT; indicates inflammation along the vein.

Asymmetrical calf swelling

Common but not specific to DVT.

Erythema and warmth

Suggestive of inflammation or thrombosis.

Pain in the affected limb

Can occur with or without movement; can indicate venous obstruction.

Dilated superficial veins

May indicate compensatory circulation due to deep venous obstruction.

Homans' sign

Non-specific; Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with extended knee will cause tenderness in the calf.

Mose’s sign

Painful response to gentle squeezing of the lower calf from side-to-side.

Neuhof's Sign

Thickening and deep tenderness in the calf muscles upon palpation.

Phlegmasia Alba Dolens

DVT of the femoral vein causes painful congestion and edema of the leg with lymphangitis, which further increases edema (white leg).

Phlegmasia Caerulea Dolens

Extensive DVT in iliac and pelvic veins leading to a blue leg with possible venous gangrene or infarction.

What is the underlying cause of the presenting symptoms in a 21-year-old individual with chronic alcoholism who is admitted to the emergency department with confusion, tremors, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia?
questions.explanation:
WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation.

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

questions.text: A child, upon disturbing a bee hive, had several stings. After a few minutes, the child developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. Which of the following is the principal mediator of this reaction?
questions.explanation:
Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF).

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin).

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock.

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.

questions.text: A child who is exclusively fed rice water presents with a swollen abdomen and a pale, unenergetic expression, and shows signs of malnourishment with decreased serum protein and albumin levels. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Kwashiorkor

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus (Option B)

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool. Lab investigations revealed normal platelet count and urine analysis shows haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aetiology
  • The exact cause is unknown.
  • Immune-mediated vasculitis, often following an upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition, with HLA-B34 and DRB1, was observed in some cases.
  • Most common in Males.

 

 

Pathology and Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation of small blood vessels affecting skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys.
  • Triggered by immune system response to infections.
  • Leakage of fluid and blood cells into tissues.
  • Immune complex deposition, particularly IgA, in affected vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Palpable Purpura: Raised, purplish-red rash, mainly on lower limbs and buttocks.
  • Joint Involvement: Joint swelling, commonly in knees and ankles.
  • Abdominal Pain: Often severe, may include vomiting, diarrhoea, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception
  • Renal Involvement: Less common, presents as Chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

  • Palpable purpura plus at least one of:
    • Diffuse abdominal pain
    • Arthritis or arthralgia
    • Biopsy-proven IgA deposition
    • Renal involvement (hematuria &/ proteinuria)


Laboratory involvement:

  • Elevated ESR or CRP indicates inflammation.
  • Platelet Counts are normal.

Complications
  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic Renal Failure due to Long-term kidney damage, in severe cases.
  • Neurological Complications: Rare; may include seizures, headaches, or peripheral neuropathy.

Treatment
  • Mild Cases: Rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
  • Moderate to Severe Cases: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation.
  • Severe or Resistant Cases: Additional immunosuppressive medications may be required.

Prognosis
  • Full recovery in most cases.
  • Variable based on renal involvement.

Fluid-filled antrum appears, granulosa and theca cells differentiate. Prepares for ovulation.

Graafian follicle

Fully matured, large antrum, ready for ovulation.

Corpus luteum

Formed after ovulation, secretes progesterone to support pregnancy. If there is no fertilization, it degenerates.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her paediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Atrial septal defect

Feature

Description

Left-to-Right Shunting

Oxygenated blood flows from the left to right atrium; the degree of shunting varies with defect size and vascular resistance.

Right Heart Volume Overload

Increased blood flow causes enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle, and dilation of the pulmonary artery.

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance

May increase with time, after remaining low during childhood, and lead to reversal of shunt and cyanosis.

Symptoms

Description

Asymptomatic

Many children are asymptomatic.

Failure to Thrive

Poor growth and weight gain.

Exercise Intolerance

Difficulty with physical activity.

Finding

Description

Widely Split and Fixed S2

The second heart sound is split and fixed due to increased right ventricular diastolic volume.

Systolic Ejection Murmur

Soft murmur at the left upper sternal border, caused by increased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract.

Mid-Diastolic Murmur

Rumbling murmur at the lower left sternal border due to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

Correct Answer D - Hypoglycemia

Macrosomia/Large for Date Baby
  • Increased risk of birth trauma if forceps are used in obstructed labour.
  • Increased chances of perinatal asphyxia in prolonged labour.

Metabolic
  • Hypoglycemia (vs Option A)
  • Hypocalcemia (vs Option C)
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Neonatal jaundice

CVS
  • The most common congenital abnormality in infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) is congenital heart disease (CHD).
  • The most common congenital heart disease in IDM is ventricular septal defect (VSD). (vs Option B)
  • The most specific congenital heart disease in IDM is the transposition of the great arteries (TGA).

Respiratory System
  • Respiratory distress syndrome or hyaline membrane disease due to delayed maturation of surfactant.

CNS
  • The most common congenital neurologic abnormality in IDM: Neural tube defects.
  • Most specific neurologic abnormality in IDM: Sacral agenesis or caudal regression syndrome.

Renal
  • Renal vein thrombosis
  • Renal agenesis
  • Duplication of ureter
  • Hydroureteronephrosis

GI
  • Duodenal atresia
  • Lazy/small left colon syndrome

Long Term Problems
  • Blindness
  • Obesity
  • Nonketotic hypoglycemia
  • Deafness

questions.text: A 5-year-old male with a known history of asthma developed sudden onset breathlessness and wheezing. He was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization

options.label: B
options.text: High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only

options.label: C
options.text: Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety

options.label: D
options.text: Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization

Life-Threatening Asthma Management

Overview
  • Most severe asthma exacerbations require immediate attention.
  • Indicators: Cyanosis, silent chest, poor respiratory effort, exhaustion, altered mental state, PEF <30%, oxygen saturation <90%.

Immediate Management
  • Oxygen Therapy: Administer for hypoxemia.
  • Systemic Bronchodilators: Terbutaline or adrenaline subcutaneously; inhaled bronchodilators (salbutamol, ipratropium).
  • Systemic Corticosteroids: IV hydrocortisone (5 mg/kg).
  • ICU Transfer: For monitoring and advanced care.

ICU Management
  • Continuous Monitoring: Vital signs, oxygen saturation, PEF.
  • If Improvement Noted:
    • Continue inhaled bronchodilators (salbutamol/terbutaline) every 20-30 minutes.
    • Maintain hydrocortisone at 2-3 mg/kg every 6-8 hours until the patient can take oral medication.
  • If No Improvement or Deterioration:
    • Consider slow intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate (50 mg/kg).
    • Alternatively, administer a loading dose of theophylline.
  • If these measures fail, prepare for mechanical ventilation.
  • Address Underlying Causes: Check for acidosis, pneumothorax, electrolyte imbalance, and infection.

questions.explanation:
Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

 

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: During wound healing, the cells that appear first, due to chemotaxis, at the site of the wound are:
questions.explanation:
Events in wound healing

Day 0

Platelets and Fibrin form blood clots.

Day 1

Blood clot remains and recruitment of neutrophils (acute inflammation).

Day 2

Blood clots remain; neutrophils accumulate, followed by the formation of a thin epithelial layer.

Day 3

Chronic inflammation sets in, and macrophages replace neutrophils.

Granulation tissue begins (blood vessel formation starts)

Day 5
  • Maximum granulation tissue (Maximum neovascularisation)
  • Collagen bridging starts

Day 21(3rd Week)

Maximum collagen deposition (Type I collagen.)

Primary intention

Secondary intention

Primary intention healing involves rapid closure of a clean, surgically closed wound with minimal tissue loss, resulting in a small scar.

E.g., Surgical scar.

Secondary intention healing occurs when a wound is left open to granulate and epithelialise, often resulting in a larger scar and longer healing time.

Associated with wound contraction. e.g., Road traffic accidents.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who has been working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT of the chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. What is the person suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Occupational Lung Disease

Associated Agents

Features

Diagnostic Tools

Preventive Measures

Asbestosis

(Option A)

Asbestos fibers

Characterised by progressive pulmonary fibrosis. Symptoms include dyspnea, non-productive cough, and chest pain. Often associated with pleural plaques and increased risk of mesothelioma and lung cancer.

HRCT, pulmonary function tests, occupational history

Use of protective gear, proper ventilation, asbestos abatement programs

Silicosis

(Option C ruled out)

Crystalline silica (quartz dust)

Presents with nodular pulmonary fibrosis, primarily in the upper lobes. Increased risk of TB and other respiratory infections. Chronic exposure can lead to progressive massive fibrosis.

Chest X-ray, HRCT, occupational history

Dust control measures, respirators, regular health check-ups

Coal Worker's Pneumoconiosis (CWP)

(Option B ruled out)

Coal dust

Also known as "black lung disease." Features similar to silicosis but usually affect the upper lungs with coal dust deposition and fibrosis, without the silicotic nodules.

Chest X-ray, HRCT, pulmonary function tests

Dust control, respiratory protective equipment, regular monitoring

Byssinosis

Cotton, flax, hemp dust

"Monday fever" describes worsening symptoms at the beginning of the workweek. Symptoms include chest tightness and wheezing, predominantly in textile workers.

Clinical evaluation, occupational history

Improved ventilation, dust suppression, health education

Berylliosis

(Option D ruled out)

Beryllium and its compounds

Acute or chronic lung disease caused by beryllium. Chronic form mimics sarcoidosis with systemic symptoms and granulomatous inflammation.

Lung biopsy, beryllium lymphocyte proliferation test (BeLPT), imaging

Limiting exposure, personal protective equipment, medical surveillance

Farmer's Lung

Moldy hay, crops, and compost dust

A type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhaling organic dust, presenting with malaise, cough, and breathlessness that may become chronic.

HRCT, pulmonary function tests, specific IgG testing for antigens

Respiratory protective equipment, proper storage of agricultural products

questions.text: A 19-year-old male, chronic smoker, presented with fever, a painful lump over his left cheek just below the ear, and difficulty in swallowing or talking. The patient also complained of mild testicular pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mumps

Causative Organism

Mumps virus (Paramyxoviridae family)

Age Group

5-9 years mostly

Transmission

Respiratory droplets

Period of communicability

7 days before to 7 days after the onset of symptoms

Symptoms

High-grade fever, Headache, Parotitis (Often Bilateral), orchitis

Complications
  • Most Common complication in child : Aseptic Meningitis
  • Most Common complication in Adult : Orchitis ( does not lead to infertility )
  • Oophoritis, pancreatitis, myocarditis, arthritis, thyroiditis & conjunctivitis.
  • Mumps during early pregnancy increases fetal wastage but not malformations.

Neurological Complications
  • Meningitis (Most Common) - 10-30% of cases.
  • Encephalitis, transverse myelitis, and facial palsy are less common.

Treatment
  • Self-limiting
  • Management focuses on symptom relief - pain reduction, hydration, and antipyretics.

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis of CT chest shown below.

An intern observed that a patient in the ward was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed a rhythm as depicted below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
Pulsus paradoxus is seen in:

options.label: B
options.text: Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease
questions.explanation:
Pulsus Paradoxus

Definition:

A fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration.

Pathophysiology:

Exaggerated interventricular dependence → Increased right ventricular filling during inspiration shifts the septum leftward, reducing left ventricular output and causing a more pronounced drop in systolic pressure.

Associated Conditions:
  • Pericardial tamponade (classic association)
    • External pressure on the heart limits filling
    • Inspiration compresses the RV, preventing normal inspiratory RV filling
    • Interventricular septum shifts left, restricting LV filling and output → Marked fall in BP
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Severe obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, COPD)
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Effusive Constrictive Pericarditis
  • Restrictive Cardiomyopathy

Measurement:

 
  • Auscultatory method:
    • Identify the systolic pressure during expiration and independent of respiration.
    • The difference between these two is the pulsus paradoxus.
    • If the difference exceeds 15 mmHg, pulsus paradoxus may be palpable at the brachial or femoral artery.
  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, tachypnea will make it difficult to measure.

Parameter

Inspiration

Expiration

Jugular venous pressure

Falls

Rises

Blood pressure

Falls (up to 10 mmHg)

Rises

Heart rate

Accelerates

Slows

Second heart sound (S2)

Splits*

Fuses*

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient presented with complaints of dyspnea with congestive heart failure. The clinician wants to know whether it's HF with preserved EF or reduced EF. Which of the below investigation is used for calculation of ejection fraction?
questions.explanation:
Purpose

Scan types

For Myocardial Perfusion

  • Assess ischemia
  • Cold spot: decreased uptake in ischemic areas.
  • Thallium scan (Commonly used) (Option B)
  • Tetrofosmin
  • Sestamibi scan (Option D)

For Myocardial Infarction

  • Assess infarct
  • Hot spot in infarct area as pyrophosphate accumulates and is not metabolized.
  • 99m Tc - Pyrophosphate scan.

For Ventricular Function

  • Evaluate ejection fraction
  • MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan (AKA nuclear ventriculography)
    • Radiolabeled RBCs are used
  • Most accurate for ventricular function - Cardiac MRI

For Myocardial Viability

 
  • Assess the viability of myocardium
  • PETscan - Best investigation for myocardial viability. (Option C)
    • Perfusion and metabolism mismatch are observed in the PET scan.
    • Perfusion Agents:N-13 ammonia and Rubidium chloride.
    • Metabolism Agent: FDG-PET is used for glucose metabolism.
      • No FDG uptake indicates a normal heart or an infarct.
      • FDG uptake is present: In the Ischemic Myocardium
    • FDG-PET is combined with perfusion imaging for comprehensive assessment.
      • Uptake in PET with low perfusion indicates reversible dysfunction (suggestive of hibernation).
      • Irreversible dysfunction indicates the presence of scar tissue.
    • Note: Hibernating myocardium is ischemic but viable.

questions.text: In case of corrosive acid ingestion, stomach is opened along the?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Greater curvatu

Organ

Dissection Method

Key Features

Brain

Cerebrum

  • It is separated from the cerebellum and brainstem with a horizontal cut.
  • Sliced coronally at 1 cm intervals.
  • Fixed brains sliced through mammillary bodies, then coronally.
  • Asymmetry, brain shift, old infarcts, focal lesions, ventricle dilation, cortex shrinkage, fat emboli, petechial hemorrhage, and edema.

Cerebellum

  • Horizontally dissected in a ‘fan’ shape.
  • Middle slice through the dentate nucleus.
  • Structural abnormalities such as hemorrhages and lesions.

Brainstem

  • Sliced perpendicular to its axis at 5 mm intervals.
  • Hemorrhages, softening, cystic degeneration, and tumors.

Heart

Inflow-outflow

  • Open the right atrium, tricuspid valve, and pulmonic valve.
  • Open left atrium, mitral valve, and aortic valve.
  • Best for systematic chamber and valve evaluation.

Ventricular Slicing

  • First, slice 3 cm from the apex.
  • Parallel slices 1 cm apart.
  • Rest opened along with blood flow.
  • Useful for suspected ischemic myocardial disease, shows infarction distribution.

Sandwich Technique

  • The knife slices the left ventricle muscle.
  • The myocardium opened like a book.
  • Exposes infarcts or fibrotic plaques in the myocardium.

Spinal Cord

Posterior Approach

  • Long midline incision, flap skin and muscle outward.
  • Posterior arch cut with a saw.
  • Remove spinal processes and laminae.
  • Open dura and cut nerves for spinal cord removal.
  • Lesions along the spinal cord and surrounding tissues.

Intestine
  • The entire length is dissected.
  • Injuries, poison reactions, foreign bodies (bullets), ulcerative colitis-like lesions (mercuric chloride poisoning).

Liver
  • Remove and weigh.
  • Multiple transverse sections 1–2 cm apart.
  • Hepatomegaly (inflammation, neoplasia) or shrunken liver (cirrhosis). Gallbladder pathology (stones, inflammation).

questions.text: A 72-year-old farmer was presented in the hospital with pinpoint pupil & increased secretions. The diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Organophosphorus poisoning

Symptoms

Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS)

Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis

CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. He has a history of inferior-wall myocardial infarction a year ago. Holter study was done and his 24 hour ECG strip obtained is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Sinus bradycardia

Definition

Sinus bradycardia is a cardiac rhythm with normal sinus node depolarization but a rate < 60 bpm.

Diagnostic Criteria

ECG showing sinus rhythm at a rate lower than 60 bpm.

Common Etiologies
  • Normal in athletes
  • Medications (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin)
  • Hypothyroidism, hypothermia
  • Sick sinus syndrome, myocardial infarction
  • Vagal stimulation (e.g., vasovagal syncope)

Clinical Features
  • Asymptomatic (in many patients)
  • Fatigue
  • Dizziness or lightheadedness
  • Exercise intolerance
  • Syncope or presyncope
  • Cognitive slowing
  • Worsening angina or heart failure symptoms

Evaluation
  • Assess hemodynamic stability
  • ECG to confirm sinus rhythm
  • Review medication list for bradycardic agents
  • Evaluate for comorbidities (e.g., hypothyroidism, myocardial infarction)

Management
  • If Hemodynamically Unstable:
    • IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes (max 3 mg)
    • If there is no improvement, consider a temporary pacemaker
  • If Stable, for long term mamagement:
    • Treat underlying causes
    • Withdraw bradycardia-inducing medications
    • Permanent pacemaker

questions.text: Which among the following conditions does not result in the development of a grey-white membrane over the tonsils?
questions.explanation:
Ludwig’s angina- Anatomy

Primary Spaces

It involves three spaces around the mandible: the sublingual, submandibular, and submental spaces.

  • Sublingual space: Infections here typically arise from the premolars and first molar.
  • Submandibular space: It contains the submandibular gland and lymph nodes, and connects to both the sublingual and submental spaces.
  • Submental space: Infections in the submandibular space can easily spread to the submental and contralateral sublingual spaces.

Secondary Spaces

 
  • The secondary spaces, known collectively as the masticator space, surround the muscles involved in mastication (masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis).
  • These spaces can become involved due to the posterior spread of infection from the primary spaces or from a third molar infection.
  • The primary clinical feature of masticator space infection is significant trismus.

Structures Present

questions.text: A patient with Pink color skin & mucosa, a bitter almond smell from breath, and frothy discharge. The cause of death is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - HCN poisoning

Cyanide poisoning

Physical Appearance
  • Gaseous state- Hydrogen cyanide (HCN)
  • Liquid form- Hydrocyanic acid or Prussic acid
  • Solid state- salt forms

Sources of poisoning
  • Electroplating, photographic processes, rubber, and plastic manufacturing industries
  • Insecticide and rodenticide
  • Drug toxicity: Sodium nitroprusside
  • Military chemical warfare agents
  • Burning of plastic furniture, silk, or wool
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Bitter almonds, peach, apricot, plum, apple, pear, cassava

Mode of Action
  • Rapid absorption across both skin and mucous membrane
  • Cyanide salts combine with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to form HCN that is absorbed
  • Inhibition of cytochrome oxidase causes histotoxic anoxia
  • Neurotoxicity

Clinical Features
  • Inhalation: Dizziness, vertigo, and constriction of the throat
  • Ingestion: Nausea, headache, loss of muscular power, hypotension, cardiovascular failure, and convulsion
  • Skin: Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Anion gap metabolic acidosis and lactic acidosis

Diagnosis
  • Lee-Jones test
  • Serum cyanide level

Treatment
  • Severe acidosis (pH < 7.1): Administer sodium bicarbonate
  • Antidotal therapy (Eli Lilly cyanide kit approach)
    • First step: Inhalation of Amyl nitrite
    • Second step: Sodium nitrite (3% solution) IV
    • Third step: Sodium thiosulfate (25% solution) IV
  • Other Antidotes
    • 4-dimethylaminophenol (4-DMAP)
    • Hydroxocobalamin (Vitamin B12): Combines with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted in the urine
    • Hyperbaric oxygen
  • Note: Methylene blue is NOT an antidote for cyanide and must NOT be used

Autopsy Findings
  • Bitter almond’s odour
  • Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Cyanosis of extremities
  • Hemorrhagic gastritis
  • Disseminated petechiae in brain, meninges, pleura, lungs, and pericardium
  • Pulmonary and cerebral edema

questions.text: Which of the following findings from a pleural fluid aspirate will suggest an exudative pleural effusion? Normal values Total S. Protein: 6-8 gm% S.LDH: 140-280 IU S. glucose: 140-200

options.label: A
options.text: Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > ⅔ of serum LDH

options.label: B
options.text: Pleural fluid protein = 4.5 gm% and glucose = 30 mg%

options.label: C
options.text: Pleural fluid LDH = 90IU and glucose = 30 mg%

options.label: D
options.text: Pleural fluid protein = 3.5gm% and glucose = 90 mg%

questions.correct_answer: A. Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > ⅔ of serum LDH
questions.explanation:
Radiological investigation

X-ray:

  • 200 mL of fluid is needed for detection on the posteroanterior (PA) view.
  • 50 mL of fluid may lead to blunting of the costophrenic angle on the lateral view.
  • A homogeneous opacity with obliteration of the costophrenic angle is typical.
  • This appearance is marked by a curved upper border, known as the Ellis S-shaped curve.
  • Obliteration of cardiophrenic angle.

Ultrasound: More effective than X-ray in detecting fluid presence, showing a clear hypoechoic space indicative of transudate and moving densities suggesting exudate.

Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Additional Tests for Exudative Effusions
  • Appearance description
  • Glucose level, If Glucose <60 mg/dL Consider:
    • Malignancy
    • Bacterial infections (empyema)
    • Rheumatoid pleuritis
  • Differential cell count
  • Microbiologic studies
  • Cytology

Standard Peculiarities

  • Heart Failure: NT-proBNP level > 1500 pg/mL indicates effusion due to congestive heart failure
  • Parapneumonic Effusion: Key criteria include:
    • Loculated pleural fluid
    • Pleural fluid pH < 7.20
    • Pleural fluid glucose < 3.3 mmol/L (< 60 mg/dL) ( Option B, C)
    • Positive Gram stain or culture results
    • Presence of visible pus
  • Tuberculous Pleuritis: Diagnosis confirmed by high TB markers in pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase > 40 IU/L or interferon γ > 140 pg/mL)

questions.text: The image given below is from a chronic smoker’s oral examination. Identify the lesion given.
questions.explanation:
Definition

White patch on oral mucosa, defined clinically, excluding conditions like lichen planus, candidiasis, etc.

Causes
  • Smoking, tobacco chewing
  • Alcohol abuse (especially with smoking)
  • Chronic trauma (ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites)
  • Associated with submucous fibrosis, hyperplastic candidiasis, Plummer-Vinson syndrome

Common sites
  • Buccal mucosa (most common in India)
  • Oral commissures, floor of mouth, tongue, gingivobuccal sulcus, lip mucosa

Age & Gender
  • Men in their 40s are 2-3 times more affected than females.

Clinical types
  • Homogenous: Smooth or wrinkled white patch, lower malignancy risk
  • Nodular (speckled): White patches on an erythematous base, higher malignancy risk
  • Erosive (erythroleukoplakia): Interspersed with red patches, fissures, highest malignancy risk

Malignant potential
  • 1-17.5% risk, average 5% malignant transformation
  • Higher risk in dysplastic lesions and certain locations

Treatment
  • Remove causative factors: Spontaneous regression in some cases.
  • Biopsy: For lesions with high malignant potential.
  • Surgical excision or laser/cryotherapy: For suspicious or small lesions

Diagnosis of filariasis

1.

Thick blood film
(Investigation of choice)

Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM

Lymphatic filariasis

Brugian/Malayan filariasis

Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei

Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei

2.

Rapid Detection Test
  • Also called the filarial strip test
  • Used for monitoring, mapping, and evaluation activities

3.

Membrane filter concentration method
  • Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia
  • Require specialized equipment.

4.

  • A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour

questions.text: What is the primary source of arterial supply for the palatine tonsils among the options provided?

options.label: A
options.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

options.label: B
options.text: Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery

options.label: D
options.text: Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
questions.explanation:
Anatomy of Palatine tonsils

Location

Lateral wall of the oropharynx between the anterior and posterior pillars.

Surface Extensions

Upwards into the soft palate, downwards into the base of the tongue, and anteriorly into the palatoglossal arch.

Medial Surface Epithelium
  • Stratified squamous epithelium with crypts.
  • Crypta magna, or intratonsillar cleft, is located near the upper part of the tonsil.

Lateral Surface

It is covered by a fibrous capsule separated from the tonsil bed by loose areolar tissue.

Tonsil Bed Muscles

Formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

Arterial Supply
  • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (main supply)
  • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • Dorsal linguae branches of the lingual artery
  • Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery.

Venous Drainage

It drains into the paratonsillar vein, which joins the common facial vein and the pharyngeal venous plexus.

Lymphatic Drainage

Flows into the upper deep cervical nodes.

Sensory Nerve Supply

Lesser palatine branches of the sphenopalatine ganglion (CN V) and the glossopharyngeal nerve.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old male who has been experiencing eye pain, sensitivity to light, and redness for the last two days, following an injury caused by brushing his eyes against leaves and thorns while gardening?
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma) (Option C)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions: Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer
  • Perforation: Rare but possible

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

 

BACTERIAL KERATITIS (Option B)

FUNGAL KERATITIS

Etiology
  • S. aureus (worldwide)
  • S. epidermidis (India)
  • Aspergillus

Examination Findings
  • Fluorescein stain positive ulcer
  • Hypopyon (sterile)
  • Stromal edema
  • Descemet’s membrane folds
  • Keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis
  • Signs >>> symptoms
  • Dry/rough ulcer
  • Has projecting ends
  • Thick immobile unsterile hypopyon
  • Satellite nodules are infective and have immune reaction- Wessley ring
  • IOP is high

Treatment
  • Empirical monotherapy: Moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin, besifloxacin
  • Duo therapy: Gram positive + gram negative. Combination of Cefazolin with Gentamicin or Cefuroxime with Gentamicin.
  • Cycloplegics and mydriatics
  • Antifungals: Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B
  • Steroids are contraindicated

What is the probable diagnosis for a neonate who presents with symptoms of photophobia and excessive tearing, along with a clinical examination showing a normal tear passage and a clear, but abnormally large cornea, and the presence of Haab's striae in the eye image below?
questions.explanation:
Types
  • Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  • Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  • Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

 

(Buphthalmos: meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.)

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

 

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a female patient, aged 65, who visits the outpatient department with symptoms of breathlessness and fatigue? During examination, the patient's neck veins were engorged, and her jugular venous pulse displayed a swift X and Y descent.
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

System

Manifestations

Pulmonary system
  • Pleuritis (most common): Prevalence (30 - 50%)

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a man of 45 years who arrives at the emergency department with an abrupt loss of vision and experiencing painful movements of the eye? Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is observed in the affected eye. Further visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma in the same eye.
questions.explanation:
Classification of Optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis

Retrobulbar Neuritis

Neuroretinitis (Option D)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features
  • Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.
  • A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).
  • Optic atrophy present

Clinical features
  • Visual loss: Monocular sudden, progressive and profound visual loss is the hallmark of acute optic neuritis.
  • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
  • Visual obscuration in bright light is a typical symptom of acute optic neuritis.
  • Impairment of color vision is always present in optic neuritis.
  • Uhthoff's symptom: Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat, occurs in patients with isolated optic neuritis.
  • Pulfrich's phenomenon: Depth perception may be impaired, particularly for the moving object.
  • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
  • Visual field changes: The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.

Management of Optic neuritis:

Treatment

Indications

Details

Conservative management

(Observation and Monitoring)
  • Mild symptoms
  • Known history of similar episodes
  • Many cases improve spontaneously.
  • Suitable for mild symptoms but not recommended for severe cases or first episodes.

High-Dose Corticosteroids
  • Severe vision loss
  • No history of previous episodes
  • MRI evidence of demyelination
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone taper as established by the ONTT trial (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial).

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 14-year-old male who has been experiencing repeated nosebleeds, without any history of injury, along with nasal blockage and excessive nasal discharge? During examination, a solid, purplish growth is observed on the back of the nasopharynx.
questions.explanation:
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Site of Origin

Posterior nasal cavity, near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen, where the sphenoid and palatine bones meet.

Gross Appearance

Reddish-purple, lobulated, sessile mass covered by mucosa; lacks a capsule despite being benign.

Microscopic Appearance
  • Vascular Tissue: Endothelium-lined spaces with incomplete/absent muscle coats, leading to bleeding; peripheral vessels are thin-walled, central vessels hyperplastic.
  • Stromal Cells: Stellate or spindle-shaped cells that produce collagen, affecting tumor firmness.

Immunohistochemistry
  • Fibroblasts, collagen, myofibroblasts, mast cells, and occasionally giant cells are present.
  • Reactivity to smooth muscle actin and beta-catenin, suggesting beta-catenin’s role in growth.

Growth Factors
  • JNA development likely results from a combination of hormonal influence, growth factors, and genetic factors.
  • Androgen Receptors: Present in 75% of JNA tumors, indicating male hormone involvement.
  • VEGF: Promotes endothelial and stromal cell growth.
  • IGF-II: Role is less clear.
  • Genetics: C-MYC proto-oncogene found in larger tumors; may interact with androgen receptor and beta-catenin genes.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions leads to the development of wing beating tremor?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Wilson's Disease

Hepatic Symptoms
  • Chronic Hepatitis: Jaundice, hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes due to copper accumulation in the liver.
  • Cirrhosis: Portal hypertension, variceal bleeding as a result of long-term copper accumulation and fibrosis.
  • Acute Liver Failure: Coagulopathy, jaundice, encephalopathy.

Neurological Symptoms
  • Movement Disorders: Tremors (flapping or wind-beating tremor), dystonia, ataxia, dysarthria due to copper accumulation in the basal ganglia.
  • Parkinsonism-like symptoms : Rigidity, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity from copper accumulation in the basal ganglia.
  • Psychiatric: Depression, personality changes, cognitive decline.

Ocular Features
  • Kayser-Fleischer Rings: Brown/greenish rings in the cornea due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane.

 

  • Sunflower Cataract: Rare, (copper deposition in the lens).

Renal Features
  • Renal Tubular Acidosis (Fanconi Syndrome): Due to copper accumulation in renal tubules.

Hematologic Features
  • Hemolytic Anemia: Copper-induced red cell damage.

Skeletal Features
  • Osteopenia, osteoporosis, joint arthropathy

questions.explanation:
• It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.
  • Type I & IV HSR reaction > Type IV HSR

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance; bluish-white color; dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots

Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).

  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.
  • Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing
