questions.text: What is the preferred medication for treating Hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Management of Hyperthyroidism in Pregnancy

Medical Management

First Trimester:

  • Propylthiouracil 100-300mg/day (three times daily)
  • Mechanism: Inhibits hormone synthesis + Thyroxine to Triiodothyronine conversion

Second/Third Trimester:

  • Methimazole 5-15mg/day (once daily)

Monitoring:

  • Thyroid Function Tests every 2-4 weeks
  • Thyroid Stimulating Hormone Receptor Antibodies: 18-22 weeks, 30-34 weeks
  • Target: Free Thyroxine upper normal, Thyroid Stimulating Hormone slightly low

Thyroid Storm Protocol
  1. Propanolol
  2. Potassium Iodide/Lugol's solution (60 minutes post-antithyroid drugs)
  3. Propylthiouracil/Methimazole administration
  4. Glucocorticoids
  5. Intensive care support
  6. Mortality: 20-30% if untreated

Teratogenicity

Methimazole Embryopathy:

  • Aplasia cutis
  • Choanal/esophageal atresia
  • Dysmorphic facies

PTU Associated:

  • Isolated anomalies
  • Situs inversus
  • Renal tract malformations

Contraindications
  • Radioactive iodine
  • First trimester thyroidectomy

Fetal Surveillance

Ultrasound markers:

  • Thyroid dimensions
  • Fetal heart rate (>160/min significant)
  • Growth parameters
  • Hydrops features
  • Bone maturation

questions.text: A COVID patient presented with fever, nasal congestion, and unilateral headache. Later, he developed facial pain and numbness, along with a blackish lesion. On Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA), a cotton-wooly growth is seen. H&E staining shows non-septate hyphae branching at right angles/obtuse angles. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus:

 Absidia

 Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained):

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. 

b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

 

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

questions.text: PR segment in ECG indicates:
questions.explanation:
Component

Cause

Normal Duration and Size

P wave

Atrial depolarization is initiated by the SA node. (Option A Ruled Out)
  • 0.08–0.11 seconds
  • 2–2.75 small boxes
  • <2.5 mm (0.25 mV) in amplitude/ height
  • <0.12 sec (120 msec or 3 small boxes) in width

PR interval

Time from onset of atrial depolarization (P wave) to onset of ventricular depolarization (electrical impulse passing through AV node) (Option B)
  • 0.12–0.20 seconds
  • 3–5 small boxes

Q wave

Initial depolarization of the interventricular septum, directed from left to right.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • <1 small box
  • Depth: <1/4 of R wave or ~1–2 mm (<0.5 small boxes)

QRS complex

Ventricular depolarization - the time taken for the electrical impulse to spread through the ventricles. (Option C Ruled Out)
  • <0.10 seconds
  • <2.5 small boxes in width
  • Height: 5–30 mm (1–6 big boxes)

QT interval

Time from the start of ventricular depolarization to the end of ventricular repolarization.
  • Duration depends on HR.
  • HR inversely proportional QT length. Rate-corrected (QTc) 330–350 msec
  • ~11 small boxes

ST segment

Represents the early part of ventricular repolarization. It is isoelectric (flat). (Option D Ruled Out)

 
  • 0.08–0.12 seconds
  • 2–3 small boxes
  • Normally isoelectric (flat), deviations >1 small box indicate pathology

T wave

Represents the later stage of ventricular repolarization.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • 2.5–6.25 small boxes
  • Height: Varies. Normally <5 mm (1 big box) in limb leads, <10 mm (2 big boxes) in precordial leads

U wave

Unknown origin; possibly related to repolarization of Purkinje fibers or ventricular walls.
  • Not always measurable

questions.text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - 1 acre

Category

Details

Methods of Refuse Disposal

1. Dumping: Unsatisfactory; becomes a nuisance.

2. Controlled Tipping (Sanitary Landfill): Most satisfactory; achieved via trench, ramp, and area methods.

  • Modified Sanitary Landfill: Compacting and covering are done once or twice a week

 

Methods of controlled tipping

a. Trench Method:

  • Used on level ground.
  • Most important method
  • Dug on level ground, 2-3 meters deep and 4-12 meters wide.
  • For a population of 10,000, a 2-meter-deep trench requires 1 acre of land.

b. Ramp Method: For moderately sloping terrain

c. Area Method: Requires supplemental earth, used in depressions or quarries.

Technique in controlled tipping
  • Physical, chemical, and bacteriological changes occur in buried refuse.
  • Temperature rises to 60°C after 7 days, killing pathogens, followed by decomposition.
  • Organic matter decomposes into innocuous soil in 4-6 months, used as manure
  • Cooling occurs within 2-3 weeks.
  • Final product: Manure used in farming.

What could be the likely diagnosis for a pregnant woman with high blood pressure, experiencing pain in the abdomen, vaginal bleeding, and a decrease in fetal movements?
questions.explanation:
Placental Abruption

Definition
  • Premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall

Types
  • Marginal abruption (partial detachment)
  • Central abruption (complete detachment)

Risk factors
  • Maternal hypertension
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Previous history of placental abruption
  • Trauma or injury during pregnancy
  • Substance abuse (e.g. cocaine, smoking)

Clinical Presentation
  • Vaginal bleeding, often accompanied by abdominal pain
  • Uterine tenderness and hypertonic contractions
  • Fetal distress or abnormal heart rate patterns

Diagnosis
  • Clinical evaluation by a healthcare professional
  • Ultrasound imaging to assess placental location
  • Laboratory tests (e.g. complete blood count, coagulation profile)

Management
  • Depends on the severity and gestational age of the fetus
  • Close monitoring of maternal and fetal condition
  • Bed rest and restriction of physical activity
  • Administration of blood products if significant bleeding
  • Delivery of the fetus, either vaginally or by cesarean section

Complications
  • Maternal hemorrhage and shock
  • Fetal growth restriction and distress
  • Preterm birth and associated complications
  • Stillbirth or neonatal death

Postpartum care
  • Monitoring for maternal hemorrhage and infection

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is:

options.label: B
options.text: Measure the length of the uterus

questions.explanation:
Karman Cannula

Definition

The Karman cannula, also known as the Karman curette, is a medical instrument used for suction-based procedures in gynecology.

Design

It is a slender, flexible, hollow tube with side perforations and a rounded tip for gentle insertion.

Uses

Mainly used for menstrual regulation (early pregnancy termination), endometrial sampling, and suction-based procedures in gynecology.

Procedure

1. The cannula is inserted into the uterine cavity through the cervix. 2. Vacuum suction is applied to aspirate uterine contents.

Advantages

Non-invasive, suitable for early pregnancy termination, less discomfort compared to some other methods.

Contraindications

Active pelvic inflammatory disease, septic abortion, ectopic pregnancy, certain uterine abnormalities.

Safety

Proper aseptic technique is crucial to prevent infection and complications.

Complications

Risks include infection, bleeding, uterine perforation, incomplete abortion, and pain.

Alternative Methods

Other methods include medical abortion (medication-induced) and surgical procedures (dilation and curettage).

Preparation

Patient counseling, informed consent, and appropriate pain management are essential.

Post-procedure Care

Monitoring for complications, providing pain relief, and advising on follow-up care.

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as:

Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60

Manifest Blindness (Option D)

Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light

Absolute Blindness

No perception of light

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".

The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Visual Acuity

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction

A patient was brought to the outpatient department with a history of trauma near the eye and now presents with symptoms of fever, severe pain, and swelling in the left eye. On examination, no abnormal findings were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum.

Etiology
  • Sinusitis: Ethmoid sinusitis (most common) carries a high risk of causing orbital cellulitis. (Option A)
  • Underlying dental problem.
  • Dacryocystitis (inflammation of the lacrimal sac).
  • Endogenous cause: Septicemia
  • Exogenous cause: Fracture or surgery of the orbit.

Causative Organisms
  • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae (most common in children)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Streptococcus pyogenes

Clinical Features
  • Preseptal cellulitis: Fever, pain, swelling, tenderness on the outer eyelid region. (Option D)
  • Orbital cellulitis: (Option A)
    • Painful, unilateral Proptosis (swelling and severe pain worsened by eye movement or pressure)
    • Restriction of eye movements (due to proptosis)
    • Decreased visual acuity

Staging

Modified Chandler staging system:

  • Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to the orbital septum) (Option D)
  • Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess
  • Stage IV: Orbital abscess
  • Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

Treatment

  • Antibiotics (IV): Empirical therapy treats orbital cellulitis by giving Ceftazidime, Vancomycin, and Metronidazole.
  • Monitoring of optic nerve function
  • Surgery: Drainage of an orbital abscess or infected sinuses should be considered if there is a lack of response to antibiotics.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is most frequently used for recurrent pterygium?
questions.explanation:
Management

Reassurance/Observation: if not causing any visual problems (Option C)

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique: (Option D)
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft: (Option A)
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
    • Less recurrence rate
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.text: The minimum requirements of a health worker job are given: should be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and have a formal education till 8th standard. What is the health worker called?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - ASHA worker

ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade.

Population Norm for ASHA

The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Role and Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare.
  • Counselor: Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning.
  • Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition.
  • Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications.
  • Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness.

Specific Responsibilities of ASHA
  1. Promote health and sanitation practices.
  2. Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health.
  3. Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments.
  4. Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services
  5. Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS).
  6. Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies.

Role and Integration with Anganwadi

The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education.

Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives)

ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance.

Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Disability-adjusted life years (DALY)

Quality-adjusted Life Years (QALY)

(Option A)

 
  • Quality and quantity of life lived.
  • Assesses number of years of life added due to the intervention and hence the benefit and value for money of the intervention
  • QALY - 1 year of life lived in perfect health
  • Positive indicator of the cost-effectiveness of an intervention.
  • Scored between 0 (death) and 1 (perfect health).

Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALY)

 
  • DALY= Years of life lost to premature death + years lived with disability
  • 1 DALY: 1 year of healthy life lost
  • It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention

Year of life lost (YLL):

  • Calculated from the number of deaths at each age multiplied by the expected remaining years of life according to a global standard life expectancy.

Years lost to disability (YLD):

  • Where the number of incident cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor reflecting the severity of the disease on a scale from 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead).

DALY = YLL + YLD

Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE) (Option B)

  • The average number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health considering the current age-specific mortality rate.
    Healthy Life Expectancy

HALE = Life Expectancy at birth + adjustment of time spent in poor health

HALE = LE-DALY

Life Expectancy

  • Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rate.

Sullivan’s index (or DFLE) (Option D)

  • Disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) with the current pattern of mortality and disability.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. The per vaginal examination is shown below, and a blush swelling is seen along with it. What is the likely cause of her condition?
A man suffered trauma to the eye from a punch while fighting with another person. What is the most common site of fracture in orbit?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Blow-out orbital fractures result from trauma causing backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in intraorbital pressure, leading to a resultant fracture.

Classification
  • Pure blow-out fractures: Not associated with involvement of the orbital rim.
  • Impure blow-out fractures: Associated with other fractures in the middle third of the facial skeleton.

Clinical Features
  • Periorbital oedema and blood extravasation (e.g., subconjunctival ecchymosis)
  • Emphysema of the eyelids, more common with medial wall fractures
  • Paraesthesia and anaesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip, and upper teeth)
  • Ipsilateral epistaxis (bleeding from maxillary sinus)
  • Proptosis, often due to orbital oedema and haemorrhage
  • Enophthalmos (due to orbital fat escape, muscle entrapment, and cavity enlargement)
  • Diplopia

Radiography
  • X-ray: Water’s view shows ‘hanging drop’ opacity of the superior maxillary antrum due to herniated orbital contents.
  • CT/MRI: Coronal sections show extent of the fracture and herniation- hanging drop or tear drop sign

Management

General Measures and Medical Treatment:

  • Avoid nose blowing
  • Systemic antibiotics to prevent sinus infection
  • Analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Cold compresses to decrease swelling

Surgical Management:

  • Optimal surgery time: 10-14 days after injury
  • Surgical indications: Persistent diplopia, large herniation, tissue incarceration, enophthalmos >3mm

Orbital Surgeries:

  • Orbitotomy: 4 approaches: anterior, lateral, transfrontal, and temporofrontal
  • Exenteration: Removal of all orbital contents and periorbita through an incision along orbital margins.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a malodorous vaginal discharge that started a week earlier. On examination, the Whiff's test is positive, and the Gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Methods

Amsel's Criteria

  • Presence of clue cells (more than 20% of the total cell population)
  • Positive whiff test
  • Vaginal pH greater than 4.5
  • Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge
 

Microscopic Examination

  • Detection of clue cells in vaginal smear
 

Molecular Methods

  • Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis using PCR

Treatment:

First-Line Treatment

  • Oral Metronidazole: 500 mg BD for 7 days
  • Tinidazole 2 g orally for 3 days

Alternative Treatment

  • Clindamycin 300 mg orally BD for 7 days

Acidic pH

Alkaline pH>7

Alkaline pH>7

Candidiasis

  • Dimorphic fungi
    • Blastospores (sacreoids)
    • Mycelia (invasion & adherence)
  • Curdy white discharge plaque on vaginal wall on removal causes petechiae
  • Out of proportion pruritus
  • Complicated/uncomplicated

Uncomplicated

  • Seen in normal women
  • Good prognosis
  • Associated with allicans

Complicated

  • In immunocompromised (in DM, TB, pregnancy etc)
  • Recurrent, severe
  • Associated with non-allicans

Treatment

  • Azoles
    • Oral
    • Fluconazole
    • Rx both male & female

Bacterial Vaginosis

  • Hemophilus vaginalis aka Garderella vaginalis
  • Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis require the presence of at least three out of the following five criteria

1. Presence of clue cells (>20%) on microscopic examination

2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5

3. Positive whiff test with KOH (fishy odor)

4. Thin, white homogeneous vaginal discharge

5. Fishy odour

Treatment

  • Metronidazole
  • Rx the women (no sexual transmission)

Trichomoniasis

  • By Trichomonas vaginalis flagellate protozoan
    • Motile organism causes severe irritation & severe pruritis
  • Colpitis Macularis (strawberry vagina)
  • Greenish yellow, frothy discharge

Treatment

  • Metronidazole
  • Rx both man & women

questions.text: What dose of folic acid is recommended for a woman who wants to become pregnant but has a history of pregnancy complicated with a neural tube defect?
questions.explanation:
Dose of Folic Acid

Use

400 μg daily

Standard prophylactic supplementation for all women of reproductive age to prevent neural tube defects and support overall health.

4 mg daily

High-demand situations: Multiple pregnancies, anticonvulsant therapy, haemoglobinopathies, chronic infections/diseases.

4 mg daily from 1 month before conception to about 12 weeks of pregnancy

Prevent the recurrence of neural tube defects in women with prior affected infants.

4 mg daily for at least 4 weeks post-delivery

Treat pregnancy-induced megaloblastic anaemia and replenish folate stores after childbirth.

1 mg daily with iron and a nutritious diet

Improve symptoms and aid recovery from pregnancy-induced megaloblastic anaemia.

questions.text: What is the condition characterized by painless vision loss?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors

Age > 50 years (primary risk factor), Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, Hyperlipidemia, Glaucoma (increased IOP), Smoking, Hypercoagulable states

Pathogenesis

Thrombosis driven by venous stasis, endothelial damage, and hypercoagulability

Types

Non-ischemic CRVO (Venous stasis retinopathy) (75% of cases)

  • Mild to moderate, unilateral blurring of vision
  • Fundus: Mild venous congestion and tortuosity, flame-shaped hemorrhages, mild macular edema

 

Ischemic CRVO (Hemorrhagic retinopathy)

  • Severe, sudden visual loss, massive venous engorgement, "splashed-tomato" hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema
  • Marked vein sheathing, collaterals, neovascularization, chronic cystoid edema

Investigations
  • Ocular Exam: Visual acuity, IOP, Slit-lamp exam (NVI), Gonioscopy (NVA)
  • Goldmann Perimetry and ERG: Differentiating ischemic vs non-ischemic CRVO
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): Assess retinal perfusion
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Assess macular edema, sub-retinal fluid

Treatment
  • Systemic Management: Control of systemic conditions (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hyperhomocysteinemia)
  • Medical Treatment: Intravitreal anti-VEGF (e.g., Bevacizumab), intravitreal steroids (Triamcinolone, Dexamethasone implant)
  • Laser Therapy: Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) for neovascularization
  • Surgical: Pars plana vitrectomy for complications

Complications

Neovascular glaucoma, Neovascularization of the iris (NVI), Vitreous hemorrhage, Proliferative retinopathy, Chronic macular edema

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a woman who has a previous infertility history and is currently undergoing HMG treatment, based on the following findings in the USG?
questions.explanation:
Mathur Classification of OHSS

Mild OHSS:
  • Abdominal bloating
  • Mild abdominal pain
  • Ovarian size <8cm

Moderate OHSS:
  • Moderate abdominal pain
  • Nausea + vomiting
  • Ultrasound evidence of ascites
  • Increased Ovarian size (8-12 cm)

Severe OHSS:
  • Clinical ascites/hydrothorax
  • Oliguria (<500 ml/day)
  • Hematocrit >0.45
  • Hyponatremia (sodium <134 mmol/l)
  • Hypoosmolality (<282 mOsm/kg)
  • Hypoproteinemia (albumin <35 g/l)
  • Ovarian size >12 cm

Critical OHSS:
  • Tense ascites/large hydrothorax
  • Hematocrit >0.55
  • WBC >25000/ml
  • Oliguria/anuria
  • Thromboembolism
  • ARDS

Management of OHSS:

Management:
  • Avoid pregnancy in severe & critical forms
  • Remove fluids by tapping ascites & effusion
  • Oral fluids (Mild, moderate forms)
  • IV Fluids for replacement:
    • NaCl, DNS (crystalloids)
    • Albumin, Dextran, starch (colloids)

questions.text: Which of the following is used to reduce the selection bias in a clinical trial?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Randomization

Randomisation
  • The technique where every participant will get an equal and known chance of being allocated to either the treatment group or the control group.
  • Eliminates both known and unknown confounders.
  • Selection bias is avoided by randomisation, which arises when the participants are not representative of the target population.

In a clinical trial, patients are randomly assigned to receive either a new drug or a placebo, balancing out confounding variables.

Types of Bias

Subject Bias

Investigator Bias

Analysis Bias
  • Recall bias
  • Hawthorne bias
  • Reporting bias
  • Non-response bias
  • Selection bias
    • Berksonian
    • Neyman
    • Reporting
  • Publication bias
  • Misclassification bias
  • Interviewer bias
  • Pygmalion bias
  • Golem bias (blunting of response due to demotivated observer)
  • Statistical bias

questions.text: What type of statistical diagram is used in the given text to illustrate the population change between 1983 and 1989 in a specific location?
questions.explanation:

Image

Explanation

Simple Bar Diagram

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups

​​Compound Bar Diagram

  • There are gaps (discrete data) represented with multiple bars.
  • It is qualitative in the first quarter.
  • It is a Multiple bar diagram/Compound bar diagram.

Component Bar Diagram

  • Same bar has been divided into different components and each component represents its frequency.
  • It is a frequency of discrete variables.
  • It is known as the Component bar diagram.

Histogram (Option A)
  • It is not a bar diagram.
  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

questions.text: In the image provided, which refractive error is observed in the depicted condition?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.

Pathology
  • Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features
  • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism (uncorrectable by glasses) (Option B)
  • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, and halos around lights
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation
  • Visual loss primarily from irregular astigmatism and myopia, secondary loss from corneal scarring

Examination Findings
  • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
  • Placido Disc Irregularity: Irregular circles.
  • Slit-Lamp Examination:
    • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
    • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring (brownish ring around the cone due to haemosiderin in the epithelium).
    • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
  • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, disappearing with external pressure.
  • Oil Droplet Reflex: Annular dark shadow separating central and peripheral cornea in distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism.
  • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular astigmatism and progressive myopia, poorly corrected by glasses in later stages.
  • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down (seen in late stages).
  • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
  • Corneal Topography: Sensitive method for early detection, shows corneal surface shape.

Management

Spectacle Correction:

  • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
  • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.

Contact Lenses:

  • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
  • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.

Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL):

  • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
  • Involves Riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
  • Riboflavin induces cross-linking of corneal collagen to stabilize the stroma and improve contact lens tolerance.

Keratoplasty :

  • Recommended if disease progresses or in cases of acute hydrops (Descemet's membrane tear).
  • Reserved for more advanced diseases or when other treatments fail.
  • Penetrating keratoplasty is common, but Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is preferred if Descemet's membrane and endothelium are intact, reducing rejection risk.

Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) :

  • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
  • Less effective in halting progression.

questions.text: Which benefit does a patient receive when seeking treatment at an ESI hospital under the ESI Act?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Medical benefit

Benefits of ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act

Medical Benefit
  • Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit (Option A)
  • Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit
  • Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.
  • Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilization procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit (Option C)
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit (Option D)
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, and they are eligible until age 18.
  • If the daughter marries before 18, the benefit is withdrawn.

Funeral Expenses
  • It offers a cash payment of up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation

 
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month for this benefit.
  • A rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance
  • For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

Category

Description

Drug sensitive TB

Patients are sensitive to 4 TB drugs: R,H,Z,E (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol).

Mono-resistant (MR)

Resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

H-Mono-resistant (H-MR)

Resistant to Isoniazid (H) only.

Rifampicin resistant (RR) (Option C)

Resistant to Rifampicin (R) only.

Multi-drug resistant (MDR) (Option A)

Poly-Drug resistant (PDR)

Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

Extensive resistant (XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and Group 4 drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

questions.text: As a Medical Officer in charge of a Primary Health Center, you intend to engage in a conversation and address health concerns specifically with Antenatal mothers. What would be the ideal number of participants you would include in the focus group discussion?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - 6-12

Key Points

Description

Data Collection Technique

Focus Group Discussion (FGD) is a qualitative method, in the form of two-way communication

Participants

6-12 people seated in a circle, guided by a Moderator.

Role of Moderator

The active role of Leading the FGD by asking 10-12 open-ended, guiding questions.

Sociogram Purpose

Reflects the quality and interactiveness of the FGD.

Sociogram Definition

A diagram or chart created by an observer to represent the interaction dynamics during the FGD.

Role of Recorder

A separate individual is responsible for recording the discussion, with participants’ prior permission.

Data Analysis

Focuses on identifying common themes emerging from the discussion.

Communication Style

The FGD is interactive and two-way (Socratic), encouraging dialogue among participants and between participants and the Moderator.

A patient was given halothane for a surgical procedure. After a few minutes, the anesthetist noticed that he developed rigidity and hyperthermia. Which of the following ions is the reason for the above symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Definition

Rare, life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic medications (inhaled anesthetics, succinylcholine).

Inheritance

Often autosomal dominant with variable penetrance (meaning not everyone with the gene will develop the condition).

Underlying mechanism

Mutations in the ryanodine receptor (RYR1) gene cause uncontrolled release of calcium (Ca2+) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to sustained muscle contraction and heat generation.

Signs/Symptoms

Severe muscle rigidity, rapid rise in body temperature (hyperthermia), increased heart rate, metabolic acidosis.

Treatment

Dantrolene (a ryanodine receptor antagonist that reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and relaxes muscles).

What is the probable diagnosis for a middle-aged man with diabetes, who has reported a decline in vision and whose fluorescein angiography displays the depicted image?
questions.explanation:
Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR:

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

(Option D)

Mild NPDR: (Option A)

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR: (Option B)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

 

Severe NPDR: (Option C)

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants

Review in 4 months

 

Very severe NPDR:

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): (Option D)

Mild-moderate PDR:

New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria

Treatment is considered according to the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and the patient's circumstances such as reliability of attendance for review. If not treated, review in up to 2 months

High-risk PDR:

  • NVD greater than ⅓ disc area
  • Any NVD with vitreous hemorrhage
  • NVE greater than ½ disc area with vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment should be performed immediately when possible and certainly on the same day if symptomatic presentation with a good retinal view

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

It is characterized by tractional retinal detachment. Significant persistent vitreous hemorrhage and neovascular glaucoma.

Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation
